thread.title: REGION RUMBLE: Eagle’s Landing hosts Walnut Grove Friday
thread.title_full: REGION RUMBLE: Eagle’s Landing hosts Walnut Grove Friday

author: Neighbor Newspapers (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: REGION RUMBLE: Eagle’s Landing hosts Walnut Grove Friday
text: by Bill Baldowski Neighbor Newspapers October 23, 2015 04:35 PM | 142 views | 0 | | Staff / Bill BaldowskiFrom left, Ronney Daniels, defensive coordinator for the Eagle’s Landing varsity football team, goes over a play with Eagle teammates, from left, senior guard Brandon Machuca, senior nose guard Martel Waugh and senior middle linebacker Reggie McBride. slideshow Although last week’s 28-21 setback to his AAAA, region 4 opponent Locust Grove was a tough one to lose, Eagle’s Landing head coach Shawn Jones believes Friday’s home game against region foe Walnut Grove will be equally as challenging.Entering its eighth regular-season, and sixth region encounter this season, Eagle’s Landing (4-3, 2-3) and Walnut Grove (3-4, 2-3) are tied in the 4-A, region 4 standings.However, Eagle’s Landing has yet to lose on its home turf, carrying a 3-0 record into this game.Against common opponents thus far, Eagle’s Landing and Walnut Grove have lost to Spalding, 23-20 and 37-0, respectively, and Locust Grove, 28-21 and 26-20.However, each has defeated Hampton, with the Eagles taking a 38-2 win while Walnut Grove captured a 42-14 victory.Although Walnut Grove head coach Ben Reaves could not be reached for comment, Jones described the Warriors as having skilled, and very physical athletes on both sides of the football.“In addition, their defense plays an attacking brand of football,” Jones said.“Walnut Grove is relentless in coming after you.”Although his team is very detailed-oriented on offense and defense, Jones said the Eagles will have to limit any small mistakes they may have, “and prevent them from becoming big mistakes, which Walnut Grove can capitalize on.”“Of course, we have got to also continue to limit our turnovers as Walnut Grove can quickly turn fumbles and interceptions into points,” he said.“Just like any other team in our region, mistakes can not only derail your offensive drives but can ignite your opponent and completely turn a game around.”Jones is hoping his defense can employ the “three downs and out” strategy.“We have got to limit their offense to three plays, prevent them from gaining a first down as much as possible and then forcing them to bring on their specialty team and punt the ball,” he said.Statistically, Eagle’s Landing has been averaging, per game, about 338 yards total offense this season, with at least 185 coming through its ground attack and 153 in passing.In contrast, Walnut Grove is averaging 174 yards rushing per game and 125 passing for a total of about 200 yards total offense.Eagle’s Landing senior running back Antonio Gibson is pacing the Eagle’s ground assault.Through his first six games, Gibson, who is in his first year being used primarily as a ball carrier, has amassed 571 yards rushing on 72 carries, a 7.9 yards-per-carry average.He has also scored six touchdowns and has surpassed 100 yards rushing in two games thus far this season.However, Gibson hasn’t forgotten his pass receiving skills this year.Coming out of the backfield, he has 27 receptions for 339 yards, an average of just over 12 yards a reception, and has two touchdowns through the air.The Warriors leading rusher is junior running back Tydre Colquitt who has, this year, rushed for 651 yards on 131 carries, a 5.0-yards-per-carry average, and six touchdowns.The Warriors’ second leading rusher is its junior quarterback Isaiah Clark, who has compiled 166 yards on the ground this year on 77 carries, about a three-yard-per-carry average, and has scored three touchdowns. Walnut Grove’s leading pass receiver this year is junior Dashun Smith, who has recorded 32 catches for 325 yards, about 11 yard average per reception.On defense, Eagle’s Landing is being paced by a trio of players.Junior cornerback Cameron Miller has 15 solo tackles in six games while junior cornerback Tre Sherman has compiled 12 solos in five games.In addition, Eagle senior middle linebacker Reggie McBride has 17 solo and three assist tackles while senior defensive tackle Martel Waugh has 17 solos stops, four assists for a total of 19 tackles.Walnut Grove’s defense is led by five tacklers, part of the attacking defense Jones described.In six games, sophomore linebacker Conner Hicks has stymied opposing offensive units, having amassed 71 total tackles in six games, including 35 solo stops and 36 assists.In addition, Walnut Grove has four other defensive standouts with whom Eagle’s Landing will have to block as much as possible.They include sophomore defensive end Javarious Phillips, who has 55 total tackles, while sophomore linebacker Mike Smith has 35.
